newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybeans end down on speculative selling.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybeans end down on speculative selling.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended down on Friday on speculative selling by retail investors, traders said.
The most actively traded January 1998 contract ended at 3,350 yuan ($404) per tonne, losing 15 yuan. It opened at 3,370 yuan, hitting an intraday high of 3,377 and a low of 3,281.
July fell 49 to 3,250, September 77 to 3,295, November 98 to 3,278 and the March 1998 contract 17 to 3,368 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose to 17,400 tonnes from 15,900 tonnes.
Soybeans opened lower on speculative selling and moved around opening levels for most of the session, traders said.
"Speculative selling from retail investors was responsible for today's falls but futher sharp losses don't seem impossible given the lack of market-moving news," one trader said.
Traders said they expected to see a technical rebound in soybeans early next week.
